Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CDI-Type II: BirdCast: Novel Machine Learning Methods for Understanding Continent-Scale Bird Migration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
An interdisciplinary team of computer scientists, statisticians, and ornithologists will develop novel computer science methods and apply them to the challenge of understanding the annual migration of birds across North America, which is one of the most complex and dynamic natural phenomena on the planet. While direct observation of migrating birds is limited to a handful of birds wearing tracking devices, other sources of data provide partial information about migration that, when appropriately combined, will provide insight into migration at a scale previously unimaginable. These sources include a continent-wide network of volunteer bird watchers, night flight calls captured by a network of acoustic monitoring stations, continent-scale weather patterns gathered by a network of weather stations, and clouds of migrating birds detected at night by WSR-88D weather radar stations. To analyze these data, the team will develop two innovative machine learning techniques-Collective Graphical Models (CGMs) and Semi-Parametric Latent Process Models (SLPMs). The resulting model will be able to identify the complex conditions governing the dynamics of migration behavior including the choice of migratory pathways, the factors that influence when birds migrate, and the speed and duration of each night's movements. CGMs greatly extend the scope of phenomena that can be captured with graphical models. Under suitable conditions, a CGM is able to recover a model of the behavior of individuals using only collective observations.

For BirdCast, it will construct a model of individual bird dynamics from the collective observations provided by birders, acoustic and weather stations, and weather radar. Once the model is constructed, it will be applied to live data feeds (bird sightings, acoustic detections, radar detections, and weather forecasts) to predict bird migration in real time. SLPMs are an extension of latent process models, such as the CGM for bird migration, in which the dynamics of a process is represented by latent variables that are observed only indirectly. In an SLPM, the conditional probability distribution of each variable is modeled using flexible, non-parametric methods from machine learning, such as boosted regression trees. Introducing such flexible methods such as CGMs and SLPMs into latent variable models raises difficult challenges for model fitting and validation. Preventing over-fitting will require the creation of novel information regularization and latent model cross-validation methods to enforce latent variable semantics.

The proposed work will allow, for the first time, real-time predictions of bird migrations: when they migrate, where they migrate, and how far they will be flying. Accurate models of migration have broad application for basic research by allowing researchers to understand behavioral aspects of migration, how migration timing and pathways respond to variation in climatic conditions, and whether linkages exist between annual variation in migration timing and subsequent inter-annual changes in population size.

BirdCast will expand opportunities for the public to participate in the gathering of data and its analysis. The existing data set has more than 60 million observations, and the size is growing exponentially. Last year, volunteers contributed more than 1.3 million hours observing birds. Student engagement in the research is significant as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BirdCast has developed or collaborated in developing automated monitoring of nocturnally migrating birds that will be a standard going forward for studying regional and continental scale movements. This highly productive project resulted, so far, in 16 peer-reviewed publications, fostering collaborations with Oregon State University, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Oklahoma University, University of Delaware, European Network for Radar Surveillance of Animal Movements (ENRAM), Microsoft Research, University of Illinois Champaign-Urbana, Smithsonian, and New York University, and capturing the imagination of millions of birders and citizen scientists through weekly Internet postings and media coverage in such outlets at the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and National Public Radio.

The BirdCast project outlined the following goals:

1) To develop novel computer science methods and apply them to the challenge of understanding the annual migration of birds across North America.

2) To develop machine learning techniques to reconstruct and predict the behavior of migrating birds across North America. 

3) To develop infrastructure for collecting and making interoperable target and covariate data from multiple sources including bird observations, radar imagery, weather data, and human population data.

4) To provide daily forecasts of bird migration (a daily BirdCast) and interactive tools for visualizing and understanding models.

BirdCast data are becoming recognized for their values for applied conservation, particularly monitoring migration in areas where potential hazards exist. The project has already been cited in a Canadian court as an important primary source for information about bird migration that energy companies must review during their operations, and the project has also been directly involved in mitigation efforts at a high-profile memorial that poses hazards to birds (the Tribute in Light Memorial to September 11th).

BirdCast made distinct impacts in scientific and applied disciplines. In particular, we highlight our advances in automated techniques for remote sensing of nocturnal bird migration for three data modalities: radar, acoustic, and video.
1) We automated extraction of speed, direction, and biomass of migrating birds from scans produced by WSR 88D weather radars to produce real-time traffic reports (http://birdcast.info/reports/) that use our radar classifier in conjunction with our visualization code to produce graphics each morning of the previous nights' movements that characterize density, direction, and speed of bird migration with no human intervention and peer-reviewed publications and public presentations characterizing nocturnal bird migration. The project also developed new visualization tools to represent migration in conjunction with US and European collaborators.
2) BirdCast produced a proof of concept method of detection, classification, and visualization of flight calls in recorded and real-time acoustic data describing nocturnal bird migration without human intervention. This successful approach achieved accuracies of 95%, evaluated by precision and recall curves against human experts and based on convolutional deep learning network models that combine multiple fully connected layers into an architecture for feature extraction and classification.
3) We studied the feasibility of using pairs of ground-based cameras to detect and track migrating birds at night using reflected artificial light and, more importantly, showed the efficacy and highlighted the potential value of automating the process of detection and analysis of video data using this methodology.
Numerous citations of BirdCast research, both algorithm, scientific, and applied, have begun to appear in peer-reviewed articles. These include machine learning, ecology, and conservation. These include results from exploring methods for aligning patterns of radar data with eBird data, habitat data, and meteorological and climatological data and published numerous peer-reviewed papers describing these results.
The BirdCast team and its collaborators and collaboration provided direct opportunities for research and teaching in the relevant fields (including ornithology, ecology, migration biology, statistics, computer science, and citizen science); improved the performance, skills, or attitudes of undergraduate, doctoral, and professional women that will improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions; and provided exposure to science and technology for birders and radar ornithologists, university professors, young people in at least five birding clubs in the US, and members of the public (outreach through paper, radio, video, and Internet media) that have contacted project leaders for collaboration in arts, science projects, and media projects.

 

For a list of relevant publications from the project, please see the following:

http://birdcast.info/research/publications/
